data.title: Dalla Chiesa says No to Rome mayor center
data.meta_description: TV presenter Rita Dalla Chiesa on Wednesday turned down an offer to run for mayor of Rome for the center right. "I am pulling out, Dalla Chiesa said, stressing she has never been in politics and that "my work is a different one". (ANSA)
data.text:
TV presenter Rita Dalla Chiesa on Wednesday turned down an offer to run for mayor of Rome for the center right.

"I am pulling out, Dalla Chiesa said, stressing she has never been in politics and that "my work is a different one".

On Wednesday, reports said Northern League leader Matteo Salvini would not be attending talks called by former premier Silvio Berlusconi on her candidacy because he had not been consulted by center-right allies.

Sources said Salvini was not against Dalla Chiesa per se but against the way she was chosen by Forza Italia chief Berlusconi and rightist ally Giorgia Meloni of the small Fratelli d'Italia party.

Dalla Chiesa, 68, is the daughter of Carlo Alberto Dalla Chiesa, a Carabinieri general who successfully fought the Red Brigades terror group before being assassinated by Cosa Nostra after being named Palermo's new anti-mafia prefect in 1982.

Elections will take place mid-June to pick the successor to Ignazio Marino, who was forced out by his own Democratic Party (PD) after an expenses scandal last year.

Rome is currently being run by an extraordinary commissioner, Francesco Paolo Tronca And the PD will be taking part with three candidates in center-left primary elections.

Five mayoral candidates presented on Wednesday the signatures necessary to run: PD lawmakers Roberto Giachetti, the Lower House deputy speaker, and Roberto Morassut, as well as ex-senator Stefano Pedica; Domenico Rossi for the Democratic Center and Gianfranco Mascia for the Greens.

The anti-establishment Five-Star Movement (M5S) has also called on-line elections next week to pick a candidate for Rome mayor.

A reported 200 candidates for the city council and for mayor will post their curricula online along with a video on the M5S's blog run by founder and leader Beppe Grillo.

A reported 9,500 people have registered to vote in the online consultation, which should reportedly wrap up Monday or Tuesday.
